references: Findley, J. S., A. H. Harris, D. E. Wilson, and C. Jones. 1975. Mammals of New Mexico. University of New Mexico, Albuquerque, New Mexico. 360 pages.
Cockrum, E. Lendell & Y. Petryszyn. 1992. Mammals of the Southwestern United States and Northwestern Mexico. Treasure Chest Publications, Inc. Tucson, Arizona. 192 p.
Schmidly, D. J. 2004. The mammals of Texas. Revised ed. University of Texas Press, Austin.
Utah Division of Wildlife Resources. 2003. Utah Conservation Data Center. http://dwrcdc.nr.utah.gov/ucdc/.
Hall, Raymond E. 1946. Mammals of Nevada University of California Press, Berkely and Los Angeles, California.
Ingles, L.G. 1965. Mammals of the Pacific States. Stanford University Press, Stanford, CA. 506pp.
Fitzgerald, J.P., C. A. Meaney, and D. M. Armstrong. 1994. Mammals of Colorado. Denver Museum of Natural History and University Press of Colorado: Niwot, Colorado. 467 pp.

Findley, James S. 1987. The natural history of New Mexican mammals. The University of New Mexico
Press, New Mexico. 164 pages.
Hall, E. R. 1995. Mammals of Nevada. University of Nevada Press: Las Vegas, Nevada. 710 pp.
Frey, J. K. 2004. Taxonomy and distribution of the mammals of New Mexico: an annotated checklist Occasional Papers, Museum, Texas Tech University 240:1-32
Burt, W.H. and R.P. Grossenheider. 1976. A Field Guide to Mammals, Third edition. Houghton Mifflin Company. Boston, MA. 289 pp.
Hoffmeister, D.F. 1986. Mammals of Arizona. University of Arizona Press. The University of Arizona Press and the Arizona Game and Fish Department, Tucson, Arizona. 602 pages.
Chapman, J. A. and Willner, G. R. 1978. Sylvilagus audubonii. The American Society of Mammalogists, Mammalian Species No.106: 1-4.
Zeiner, D. C., et al., editors. 1990. California's wildlife. Vol. II. Mammals. California Dept. Fish & Game, Sacramento. xi + 407 pp.
habitat_description:
Southwest:
S. audubonii occurs in open plains, foothills, low valleys, grass, sagebrush, and scattered pinons and junipers (Burt and Grossenheider 1976). It has also been reported from vegetated urban areas, agricultural lands, and barren areas (New Mexico Department of Game and Fish 2002). It usually lives in desert grasslands (Cockrum and Petryszyn 1992). Desert cottontails are found from pinon-juniper woodland down through desert and grassland habitats (Findley 1987). They occur on grasslands on eastern plains, especially in prairie dog colonies where burrows provide excellent cover (Fitzgerald et al. 1994). The species inhabits a variety of other situtations including montane shrublands, riparian lands, semidesert shrublands and various woodland-edge habitats in Colorado (Fitzgerald et al. 1994). The range of audobonii is within the lower Sonoran Life zone and lower part of the Upper Sonoran Life zone (Hall 1995). The desert cottontail in Arizona lives primarily in the desert scrub, including the Great Basin Desertscrub and the plains-desert grasslands (Hoffmeister 1986). The home range is 0.4ha for females to over 6ha for males (New Mexico Department of Game and Fish 2002). The elevational range is from below sea level in California to 2,134m in Arizona (Chapman and Willner 1978, Hoffmeister 1986). The lethal body temperature is 44.8 degrees C (Chapman and Willner 1978). L. audubonii occurs throughout Arizona at elevations generally below the coniferous forests (Hoffmeister 1986). It is found in eastern Colorado into the foothills of the front range and in western Colorado below 2,135m (Fitzgerald et al. 1994). It is present in southern Nevada (Hall 1995). The species occurs statewide in New Mexico (Findley et al. 1975, Frey 2004). It is present in western, eastern, and northeastern Utah (Utah Division of Wildlife Resources 2003). In California, this species "inhabits most of the southern two-thirds of the state, excluding the higher elevations. Range extends north into the Sacramento Valley and surrounding foothills (Chapman and Willner 1978). Abundant to common in grasslands, open forests, and desert shrub habitats (Hall 1946, Ingles 1965). Found in more open habitats than brush rabbits." (quoted from CA WHR [Polite et al. 2007] based on Zeiner et al. 1990).

Great Plains:
In Texas, the desert cottontail frequents brushy areas with short vegetation within grasslands, creosote brush, and cactus deserts. In the Trans-Pecos, catclaw thickets, mesquite, allthorn, and various other desert shrubs and short grass habitats are preferred. This species utilizes prairie dog towns and their excavations for burrowing and hiding especially in the plains regions (Schmidly 2004).
